Award.AwardTitle: CNH: Collaborative Research: Hydrologic Transformation and Human Resilience to Climate Change in the Peruvian Andes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Climate change and accelerating glacier recession is affecting the water cycle and the future of water resources in the Peruvian Andes. In the Cordillera Blanca, the most glacierized mountain range in the tropics, the natural and social systems of the region are very dependent on glacial water resources and it is considered to be one of the most vulnerable to glacier-related water stress in the world. This interdisciplinary and collaborative research project will evaluate the new system of freshwater governance that is emerging in the Andes and how glacial dynamics are transforming melt water rates as they rapidly recede. The research will generate new insights into the coupled natural and human consequences of glacial recession in the tropical highlands by examining the combined effects of glacier recession on downstream watersheds, the resilience of livelihood systems and the ways in which economic change and shifting water governance are factors in this hydrologic, ecological, and social transformation. The research will also generate new hydrologic models and derive quantitative estimates of glacial water dynamics.

As glacier recession is accelerating in the Cordillera Blanca, dramatic changes in the Andean hydrologic regime pose significant challenges to Andean society. Data and observations from the project will inform water resource policy makers, global change specialists, development practitioners and scientists who study co-related topics such as chemical weathering and physical sedimentation. In examining of climate-glacier-water-society dynamics in the Cordillera Blanca, this research will provide critical information to urban residents, industries, farmers, and policymakers that will inform adaptive strategies and responses to global climate change. Integral to the project is a cross-cultural education and outreach plan that will increase awareness, inform policy managers, strengthen institutional partnerships, and educate the next generation of interdisciplinary scientists at both the undergraduate and graduate level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The tropical Peruvian Andes are situated at the confluence of natural and social changes related to climate change. Glaciers in the Cordillera Blanca in northern Peru have been rapidly receding as average temperature has increased. Because precipitation in the region is highly seasonal, and the Peruvian coast is quite arid, glacial melt water from the Cordillera Blanca accounts for a critical percentage of the discharge for the Santa River basin, one of the largest watersheds along the Peruvian Pacific coast. Currently, hundreds of thousands of people there rely on glaciers for drinking water, tourism, hydroelectricity, mining, irrigation, and livestock production, and the glaciers also provide drinking water to Peru’s second largest city and fill irrigation canals for massive agricultural operations. Because the natural and social systems of the study region are so dependent on glacial melt water, it is one of the places in the world considered to be among the most vulnerable to glacier retreat.

This interdisciplinary research project evaluates the future availability of water resources in the Santa River watershed and includes researchers from the fields of hydrology, geography, and environmental history to. Overall, the project findings suggest that these resources will be limited both by glacier retreat in the Cordillera Blanca and unprecedented demand for water uses.

The intellectual merit of this transdisciplinary NSF project arises from the ways in which it links biophysical and human processes to explain how and why stream discharges have been declining, why residents are reporting significant shifts in climate-glacier-water dynamics, and how human populations have been responding to these shifts. Through the development of a holistic hydro-social framework to understand the effects of climate change and glacier retreat, this project develops a framework for combining biophysical drivers on hydrology with various human-focused water withdrawal mechanisms.

The key findings from hydrological modeling and water sampling analyses demonstrate that downstream discharge in the Santa River basin will first increase and then decrease as the glaciers retreat. However, the timing is such that the initial increase has already occurred, with streams now showing decreased flow and increasing discharge variability, especially in the dry seasons. However, demand for water resources in the Santa River basin has also increased due to rapid economic development.

Another key set of findings of this research is that because precipitation in the study region is highly seasonal, and the Peruvian coast is arid, glacial melt water from the Cordillera Blanca accounts for much of the discharge for the Santa River basin that supports downstream human populations and activities. A diminished and less consistent glacier-fed stream flow could generate problems for agriculture, power generation, tourism, and also water quality as the dissolved and suspended load in the stream flow become more concentrated.

This research also cautions that despite predictions of deterministic physical hydrologic models analyzing glacier loss from climate change, ultimately water usage is not predictable based solely on water availability, but rather is a function of coupled natural and social dynamics. The project thus integrates the often-divergent analysis of water supply (the realm of hydrologists and glaciologists) with water use (the focus of social scientists). Results further demonstrate that both ecological change and societal forces play vital roles in shaping the future of water resources and water governance.
